questions.stem: A patient presents with a 10-day episode of elevated, expansive mood, decreased need for sleep (3 hours/night), pressured speech, racing thoughts, and grandiose plans to start multiple businesses. She has not slept in 2 days and spent $50,000 on a 'business venture.' The MOST likely diagnosis is:

options.text: Bipolar I Disorder, current episode manic

questions.explanation: This presentation meets criteria for a manic episode: elevated/expansive mood lasting >1 week with ≥3 additional symptoms (decreased sleep, pressured speech, racing thoughts, grandiosity, excessive involvement in risky activities). The significant functional impairment (spending $50,000) and severity confirm mania, not hypomania. Bipolar I requires at least one manic episode. Bipolar II involves hypomania (less severe, no marked impairment). Cyclothymic Disorder involves chronic, milder mood fluctuations.

questions.stem: Which feature BEST distinguishes a hypomanic episode from a manic episode?

options.text: Hypomania lasts at least 7 days; mania lasts at least 4 days
Hypomania does not cause marked impairment in functioning or require hospitalization
Hypomania includes psychotic features; mania does not
Hypomania involves depressed mood; mania involves elevated mood

questions.explanation: The key distinction is severity and impairment: Hypomania does NOT cause marked impairment in social/occupational functioning and does NOT require hospitalization, while mania does. Duration is actually reversed—mania requires ≥7 days (or any duration if hospitalization needed), hypomania requires ≥4 days. Psychotic features can occur in mania but NOT hypomania—presence of psychosis automatically indicates mania. Both involve elevated/expansive or irritable mood.

questions.stem: Which of the following are evidence-based treatments for Bipolar I Disorder? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Lithium for acute mania and maintenance
Psychoeducation and family-focused therapy as adjuncts

questions.explanation: Evidence-based Bipolar I treatments: Lithium is first-line for acute mania and maintenance (A); Valproate is effective for acute mania (C); Atypical antipsychotics (quetiapine, olanzapine, risperidone, aripiprazole) are effective for acute mania (D); Psychoeducation and family therapy improve outcomes as adjuncts to medication (E). Antidepressant monotherapy (B) is contraindicated—it can trigger mania/hypomania or rapid cycling. Antidepressants may be used cautiously WITH mood stabilizers.

questions.stem: Match each mood disorder to its defining feature:

columns.text: Hypomanic episodes plus major depressive episodes
Chronic hypomanic and depressive symptoms not meeting episode criteria
Depressive episodes without manic or hypomanic history

questions.explanation: Mood disorder distinctions: Bipolar I requires ≥1 manic episode (depression not required for diagnosis but common). Bipolar II requires ≥1 hypomanic AND ≥1 major depressive episode—NO history of mania. Cyclothymic Disorder involves chronic (≥2 years) fluctuating mood with hypomanic and depressive symptoms that don't meet full episode criteria. MDD involves depressive episodes without any manic/hypomanic history.

questions.stem: For each medication class, select ALL conditions for which it is an evidence-based first-line treatment:
questions.explanation: First-line indications: SSRIs are first-line for MDD (col1), NOT recommended alone for bipolar. Lithium is first-line for acute mania (col2), bipolar maintenance (col4), and has unique anti-suicide properties (col5). Lamotrigine is effective for bipolar depression (col3) and maintenance (col4) but NOT effective for acute mania. This pattern highlights how different medications target different phases of bipolar illness.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Bipolar I Disorder:

Bipolar I Disorder requires at least one [BLANK1] episode, which involves elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting at least [BLANK2] (or any duration if hospitalization is required). The episode must include at least [BLANK3] additional symptoms such as decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, or risky behavior. Unlike [BLANK4] episodes, manic episodes cause marked functional impairment or may include psychotic features. The primary treatment is [BLANK5] rather than antidepressants, which can trigger manic switching.
questions.explanation: Bipolar I requires ≥1 manic episode: elevated/expansive/irritable mood for ≥7 days with ≥3 additional symptoms (4 if mood is only irritable). Unlike hypomania, mania causes marked impairment or psychosis. Treatment centers on mood stabilizers (lithium, valproate, atypical antipsychotics)—antidepressants alone can trigger mania and are generally avoided or used cautiously with mood stabilizers.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old man presents with depressed mood, insomnia, poor concentration, and suicidal ideation for 3 weeks. He also reports a period 2 years ago when he felt 'on top of the world,' slept only 4 hours nightly, started three businesses, and made impulsive purchases totaling $30,000. That episode lasted about 2 weeks.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the MOST likely diagnosis?

options.text: Past episode meeting criteria for mania
Functional impairment during past elevated episode
Monitor for manic switch if antidepressant used

centerOptions.text: Bipolar I Disorder, current episode depressed

questions.explanation: The history reveals a past manic episode (2 weeks of elevated mood, decreased sleep, grandiosity, impulsive spending causing impairment). This makes it Bipolar I regardless of current presentation. One manic episode = Bipolar I for life. Current depression is treated with mood stabilizers; antidepressants alone risk manic switching and are contraindicated. The distinction from Bipolar II is the functional impairment during the elevated episode (mania vs. hypomania).

questions.stem: A psychiatry resident is reviewing DSM-5 mood disorder criteria. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Bipolar II Disorder requires at least one manic episode. (B) Major Depressive Episode requires symptoms lasting at least 2 weeks. (C) Persistent Depressive Disorder requires depressed mood for at least 2 years in adults. (D) A hypomanic episode can include psychotic features. (E) Cyclothymic Disorder involves chronic mood fluctuations that do not meet criteria for major episodes. (F) Bipolar I Disorder can only be diagnosed after a depressive episode occurs.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (B) MDE requires ≥2 weeks duration; (C) PDD requires depressed mood most days for ≥2 years in adults; (E) Cyclothymia involves chronic subthreshold mood symptoms. Incorrect: (A) Bipolar II requires hypomania, NOT mania—mania would be Bipolar I; (D) Psychotic features automatically indicate mania, not hypomania; (F) Bipolar I requires only manic episode—depression is common but not required for diagnosis.

questions.stem: Arrange the typical medication algorithm for bipolar depression from FIRST to LAST line:
questions.explanation: Bipolar depression algorithm: (1) Optimize current mood stabilizer if on one; (2) Evidence-based monotherapy options: quetiapine (most evidence), lurasidone, lamotrigine, or lithium/valproate optimization; (3) If inadequate, consider cautious addition of antidepressant to mood stabilizer; (4) ECT for severe, treatment-resistant, or emergency cases. Note: antidepressant monotherapy is avoided throughout.

questions.stem: Review longitudinal data on the natural course of untreated Bipolar I Disorder:

questions.question: What do these data suggest about the nature of Bipolar I Disorder?

options.text: It is typically a single-episode illness
It is a highly recurrent, chronic illness
Most patients have only depressive episodes

questions.question: What implication does this have for treatment?

options.text: Treatment is only needed during acute episodes
Medication can be stopped after the first episode

questions.explanation: The data show Bipolar I is highly recurrent: nearly all patients experience multiple episodes over time, with increasing frequency. This supports the need for long-term maintenance treatment rather than episodic treatment only during acute phases. The kindling hypothesis suggests each episode increases vulnerability to future episodes, further emphasizing prevention through continuous treatment.

questions.stem: Categorize each symptom as characteristic of MANIC episode or DEPRESSIVE episode:

items.text: Decreased need for sleep (feels rested after 3 hours)
Flight of ideas or racing thoughts

questions.explanation: Manic episode symptoms: Decreased need for sleep (feels rested), grandiosity, risky activities, flight of ideas/racing thoughts, pressured speech, increased goal-directed activity, distractibility. Depressive symptoms: Worthlessness/guilt, suicidal ideation, anhedonia, fatigue, concentration problems, sleep/appetite changes. Psychomotor agitation can occur in both mania (increased activity) and agitated depression.

questions.stem: Categorize each medication by its PRIMARY indication in mood disorders:
questions.explanation: Unipolar depression: SSRI monotherapy (fluoxetine, sertraline) is first-line. Acute mania: Lithium, valproate, and atypical antipsychotics (olanzapine) are effective. Bipolar maintenance: Lithium (prevents both mania and depression), lamotrigine (primarily prevents depression). Note: Lithium appears in both acute mania and maintenance categories—it's effective for both. Lamotrigine is NOT effective for acute mania.
